# Why `healthiar` ?

::: fragment
`healthiar` is an R package (= collection of R functions) that you can use for:

-   Quantification of attributable health impacts, e.g. mortalities, YLL (life table), YLD, DALY, disease cases, ...
    -   Environmental burden of disease assessment
    -   Evaluation of the health impact of a policy
    -   Health benefits of complying with guideline
-   Assessments across multiple geographic units
-   Monte Carlo simulation for summary uncertainty
-   Monetization of health impacts
:::

# About `healthiar`

## About `healthiar` 1/2

`healthiar` offers different calculation pathways and options

![DALY = disability-adjusted life years; YLD = years lived with disability; YLL = years of life lost](images/package_overview.png){width="1750" fig-align="left"}

## About `healthiar` 2/2

Selection of `healthiar` core family members (functions)

-   `attribute_health()` impacts to environmental exposure
-   `summarize_uncertainty()` via Monte Carlo simulation
-   `compare()` two scenarios
-   `monetize()` health impacts
-   ...

## `attribute_health()` with RR

Goal: attribute COPD cases to PM2.5 air pollution exposure

::::: fragment
:::: panel-tabset
## Hard-coded input data

```{r, eval=TRUE,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|1|2-4|5|6|7|"

results_pm_copd <- attribute_health(
  erf_shape = "log_linear", # erf = exposure-response function
  rr_central = 1.369, 
  rr_increment = 10,  # μg / m^3
  exp_central = 8.85, # μg / m^3
  cutoff_central = 5, # μg / m^3
  bhd_central = 30747 # bhd = baseline health data (here: COPD incidence)
) 
```

## Pre-loaded data

::: callout-tip
`healthiar` comes with some example data that start with `exdat_` that allow you to test functions.
:::

```{r, eval=TRUE,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE}

results_pm_copd <- attribute_health(
  erf_shape = "log_linear",
  rr_central = exdat_pm_copd$relative_risk, 
  rr_lower = exdat_pm_copd$relative_risk_lower,
  rr_upper = exdat_pm_copd$relative_risk_upper,
  rr_increment = 10, 
  exp_central = exdat_pm_copd$mean_concentration,
  cutoff_central = exdat_pm_copd$cut_off_value,
  bhd_central = exdat_pm_copd$incidence
) 
```
::::
:::::

## Main results

::: fragment
`attribute_health()` outputs two lists ("folders")

-   `health_main` contains the main results

-   `health_detailed` contains more detailed results and other assessment details in sub-lists ("sub-folders")

:::

:::: fragment
::: callout-tip
Other `healthiar` functions also create `..._main` & `..._detailed` folders
:::
::::

# Example: `attribute_health()` with user-defined ERF

## `attribute_health()` with user-defined ERF

Goal: attribute COPD cases to air pollution exposure by applying a user-defined exposure response function (e.g. MR-BRT curves from Global Burden of Disease study)

-   Any function of the form *intercept + a x c\^1 + b x c\^2 + ...*

-   Any other (non-linear) function of the `function` type, as obtained from e.g. `splinefun()` or `approxfun()`

::: fragment
```{r echo=TRUE,eval=TRUE,include=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|4-8|"

results_pm_copd_mr_brt <- attribute_health(
  exp_central = 8.85,
  bhd_central = 30747,
  erf_eq_central = splinefun(
    x = c(0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 50, 70, 90, 110),
    y = c(1.00, 1.04, 1.08, 1.12, 1.16, 1.20, 1.23, 1.35, 1.45, 1.53, 1.60),
    method = "natural")
)
```
:::

## Main results

::: fragment
```{r, echo=TRUE, eval=FALSE, include=TRUE}
results_pm_copd_mr_brt$health_main
```
:::

::: fragment
::: {.absolute left=0}
```{r, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE}
results_pm_copd_mr_brt$health_main |> 
  select(impact_rounded, pop_fraction, erf_ci, exp, bhd) |> 
  knitr::kable()
```
:::
:::

<div style="height: 75px;"></div>

::: fragment
::: {.absolute left=0}
```{r, echo=FALSE, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE}

x <- c(0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 50, 70, 90, 110)
y <- c(1.00, 1.04, 1.08, 1.12, 1.16, 1.20, 1.23, 1.35, 1.45, 1.53, 1.60)

spline_func <- 
  stats::splinefun(
    x = x,
    y = y,
    method = "natural")

# Generate finer x-values
x_dense <- seq(min(x), max(x), length.out = 200)

# Evaluate the spline function at these points
y_dense <- spline_func(x_dense)

# Plot
plot(x, 
     y, 
     # main = "User-defined ERF", 
     main = "", 
     xlab = "Exposure",
     ylab = "Relative risk",
     col = "blue", 
     pch = 19)
lines(x_dense, y_dense, col = "red", lwd = 2)
legend("topleft", legend = c("Original points", "Spline curve"),
       col = c("blue", "red"), pch = c(19, NA), lty = c(NA, 1), lwd = c(NA, 2))
```
:::
:::

# Example: Iteration with `attribute_health()`

## `attribute_health()` across multiple geographic units

Goal: attribute disease cases to PM2.5 exposure in multiple geographic units, such as municipalities, provinces, countries, ...


::: fragment
```{r}
#| code-line-numbers: "|2-3|8-9|"

results_iteration <- attribute_health(
  geo_id_disaggregated = c("Zürich", "Basel", "Geneva", "Ticino", "Jura"), 
  geo_id_aggregated = c("German","German","French","Italian","French"),
  erf_shape = "log_linear",
  rr_central = 1.369,
  rr_increment = 10, 
  cutoff_central = 5,
  exp_central = c(11, 11, 10, 8, 7),
  bhd_central = c(4000, 2500, 3000, 1500, 500)
)
```
:::

::: fragment
Here the we want to aggregate results by language region (`"German", "French", "Italian"`)
:::

## Main results

::: fragment
```{r, echo=TRUE,eval=FALSE,include=TRUE}
results_iteration$health_main
```
:::

::: fragment
::: {.absolute left=0}
```{r, echo=FALSE,include=TRUE,eval=TRUE}
results_iteration[["health_main"]] |> 
  dplyr::select(geo_id_aggregated, impact_rounded, erf_ci, exp_ci, bhd_ci) |> 
  knitr::kable()
```
:::
:::

<div style="height: 200px;"></div>

# <span style="font-size: 0.8em;">Example: `summarize_uncertainty()`</span>

## `summarize_uncertainty()`

Goal: perform a Monte Carlo simulation to obtain summary uncertainty confidence intervals that combine uncertainty in different input data

1.  Use `attribute_health()` with uncertainty in ≥ 2 function arguments

::: fragment
```{r, eval=TRUE,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE}
#| code-line-numbers: "|4-5,8-9,12-13|"

results_pm_copd <- attribute_health(
  erf_shape = "log_linear",
  rr_central = 1.369, 
  rr_lower = 1.114, 
  rr_upper = 1.664,
  rr_increment = 10,
  exp_central = 8.85, 
  exp_lower = 8, 
  exp_upper = 10,
  cutoff_central = 5,
  bhd_central = 30747, 
  bhd_lower = 28000, 
  bhd_upper = 32000
) 
```
:::

::: fragment
2. Use `summarize_uncertainty()` to obtain the confidence intervals
:::

::: fragment
```{r, eval=TRUE,include=TRUE,echo=TRUE}
results_pm_copd <- summarize_uncertainty(
  output_attribute = results_pm_copd,
  n_sim = 100
)
```
:::


## Main results

::: fragment
```{r, echo=TRUE,eval=FALSE,include=TRUE}
results_pm_copd$uncertainty_main
```
:::
::: fragment
::: {.absolute left=0}
```{r, echo=FALSE,include=TRUE,eval=TRUE}
results_pm_copd$uncertainty_main |> 
  dplyr::select(-geo_id_disaggregated) |>
  knitr::kable()
```
:::
:::

## Detailed results

::: fragment
```{r, echo=TRUE,eval=FALSE,include=TRUE}
results_pm_copd$uncertainty_detailed$attribute_by_sim_disaggregated
```
:::

::: fragment
::: {.absolute left=0}
```{r, echo=FALSE,include=TRUE,eval=TRUE}
results_pm_copd$uncertainty_detailed$attribute_by_sim_disaggregated |> 
  dplyr::select(-geo_id_disaggregated, -input, -output) |> 
  dplyr::relocate(impact, .after = sim_id) |>
  knitr::kable()
```
:::

# Example: `compare()` two scenarios

## `compare()` two scenarios

Goal: compare attributable health impacts in two (policy) scenarios

::: {.fragment .nonincremental}
1.  Use `attribute_health()` to calculate burden of scenarios A & B
:::

::::: columns
::: {.column .fragment width="50%"}
```{r}
#| code-line-numbers: "|5"

scenario_A <- attribute_health(
  erf_shape = "log_linear",
  rr_central = 1.118,
  rr_increment = 10,  
  exp_central = 8.85, # EXPOSURE 1
  cutoff_central = 5, 
  bhd_central = 25000,
)
```
:::

::: {.column .fragment width="50%"}
```{r}
#| code-line-numbers: "|5"

scenario_B <- attribute_health(
  erf_shape = "log_linear",
  rr_central = 1.118,
  rr_increment = 10,
  exp_central = 6, # EXPOSURE 2
  cutoff_central = 5, 
  bhd_central = 25000,
)
```
:::
:::::

::: {.fragment .nonincremental}
2.  Use `compare()` to compare scenarios A & B
:::

::: fragment
```{r}
results_comparison <- compare(
  output_attribute_1 = scenario_A,
  output_attribute_2 = scenario_B,
  approach_comparison = "delta" # or "pif" (population impact fraction)
)
```
:::

## Comparison results

::: fragment
```{r, echo=TRUE,eval=FALSE,include=TRUE}
results_comparison$health_main
```
:::

::: fragment
::: {.absolute left=0}
```{r, echo=FALSE,include=TRUE,eval=TRUE}
results_comparison[["health_main"]] |> 
  dplyr::select(
    impact, impact_rounded,
    impact_1, impact_2,
    bhd,
    dplyr::starts_with("exp_"),
    -dplyr::starts_with("exp_ci"), # remove col "exp_ci"
    dplyr::starts_with("rr_con")) |> 
  dplyr::slice_head() |> 
  knitr::kable()
```
:::
:::
<div style="height: 100px;"></div>
::: {.fragment .nonincremental}

`health_detailed` contains

-   `results_raw` raw comparison results
-   `scenario_1` results (scenario A in our case)
-   `scenario_2` results (scenario B in our case)
:::


# Example: `monetize()` health impacts

## `monetize()` health impacts

Goal: monetize (attributable) health impacts (obtained from `healthiar` or other source)

-   *Discounting* yes/no
-   *Inflation* yes/no
-   *Stand-alone use* either monetize impact from `healthiar` or other source


::: fragment

```{r, echo=FALSE}
results_pm_copd <- attribute_health(
  erf_shape = "log_linear", # Alternatives: "linear", ...
  rr_central = 1.369, 
  rr_lower = 1.114, 
  rr_upper = 1.664,
  rr_increment = 10,  # μg / m^3
  exp_central = 8.85, # μg / m^3
  cutoff_central = 5, # μg / m^3
  bhd_central = 30747 # baseline health data: COPD incidence
) 
```

```{r}
results_monetization <- monetize(
  output_attribute = results_pm_copd,
  valuation = 20,
  discount_shape = "exponential",
  discount_rate = 0.03,
  discount_years = 5
)
```
:::

## Main monetization results

::: fragment
```{r, echo=TRUE,eval=FALSE,include=TRUE}
results_monetization$monetization_main
```
:::

::: fragment
::: {.absolute left=0}
```{r, echo=FALSE,include=TRUE,eval=TRUE}
results_monetization[["monetization_main"]] |> 
  dplyr::select(
    impact, monetized_impact, discount_rate, valuation, 
    monetized_impact_before_inflation_and_discount, 
    monetized_impact_after_inflation_and_discount) |> 
  dplyr::slice_head() |> 
  knitr::kable()
```
:::
:::

# Other `healthiar` functions

## Other `healthiar` functions

<!--  Additional existing `healthiar` functions -->

-   `attribute_lifetable()` for YLL
-   `attribute_health` for YLD (using the `dw` & `duration` arguments)
-   `get_daly` as the sum of YLL and YLD
-   `cba()` cost-benefit analysis
-   `multiexpose()` includes multiple exposures (e.g. PM2.5 & NO2) in your assessment
-   `prepare_exposure()` calculates (population-weighted) mean exposure by combining spatial exposure geographic units data 
-   `socialize()` determines burden attributable to differences in a social indicator
    -   E.g. share of health impacts due to living in a poor neighborhood (with higher exposure) instead of a rich neighborhood (with lower exposure)
-   `attribute_mod()` modifies an existing `attribute_health()` assessment
